projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: DIONYSIUS CATO His Four BOOKS OF Moral Precepts.

p.hi: Tranſlated out of Latine Hexameter, into Engliſh Meeter:

div.head: THE PREFACE.
div.l: WHEN I obſerv'd, how many Men
In manners went awry,
And groſly erred in their courſe,
From Paths of Piety;
I thought my counſel (to amend,
If happily I might)
Was not amiſs; And teach Men how,
To live in happy plight.
Now therefore (my beloved Son)
I will inform thy mind,
To walk a courſe, whereby thou may'ſt,
Both praiſe and profite find.
So then my precepts read, as that
They may be underſtood.
For why? to read and not regard,
Is to neglect thy Good.

div.head: THE INTRODUCTION.
div.l: PRay to thy God with rev'rent fear
And allways love thy Parents dear
Reſpect thy kindred with good will
Fear to offend your Teachers ſtill.
Keep what is given to thee in Truſt
And to the Court prepare thou muſt.
With upright men, walk where thou wald
To council come thou not uncall'd.
Be neat and cleanly, as thou can:
And bid Good Day to ev'ry Man.
To all Superiours, give due place.
Slight no Inferiours, with Diſgrace.
Keep your Eſtate, with ſerious care.
Be baſhful ay, where you repair.
Ply well your care in every thing:
Read Books for Learning's cheriſhing
And what ye read, ſtrive to retain.
Your Family ſeek to maintain.
Be fair ſpoken at all eſſays;
And let not anger blind your eyes.
Mock none leaſt you be mock'd again.
The pooreſt Wretch do not diſdain.
Spare not to lend, but look to whom:
And to the Judgment you muſt come.
Feaſt rarely: And ſleep in due time.
To break your Oath, abhorre the crime.
By too much wine, wrong not your health
Fight for your Countries Common wealth
Truſt nothing raſhly; I adviſe you:
Flee from all Whores; leaſt they abuſe you.
Ply Learning for your future bleſs,
Let good Men feel your Bounteouſneſs.
Avoid ill ſpeaking: Do not raill.
An honeſt Name's of great avail.
Judge righteous Judgment: By deſerts,
And patience, win your Parents hearts.
Mind well a Benefite receiv'd:
Keep watch and waird, when thou art crav'd.
Give your advice when it is ſought;
Make uſe of Valour, not for nought.
Aſſwage your anger, and ſubdue it.
Let Tops be us'd and Dice eſchew'd.
Though thou be ſtrong, no violence do;
And no Inferiour overthrow.
Covet not, what's none of thine.
Love thy Spouſe, and 'gainſt foes combine
Train up your Children vertuouſly:
Thine own Law thou muſt underly:
Speak ſpareingly at Banquet-Table,
Preſs what is juſt, when thou art able
And willingly endure Loves pain:
To love, and to be lov'd again.

div.head: DIONYSIUS CATO, HIS MORAL PRECEPTS. Tranſlated out of Latine Hexameter, into Engliſh Meeter; By J. M.
BOOK I.

lg.l: IF GOD Almighty be a Sp'rit,
Be watchfull always; And to ſleep
Let not thy Mind be bent;
Of moral Virtues hold it chief,
Next unto GOD is He, that can
Repugnant to thy ſelf in ought,
For he, that from himſelf diſſents,
If thou ſurvey the Lives of Men,
What Man is free from Crime?
Though dear to thee they ſeem:
In time, thy private profite, more
Wiſe Men their Manners ſometimes change,
And yet from fault are free.
Believe not raſhly what thy wife
For oftimes whom the Husband loves
The Wife is found to hate.
If thou [in kindneſs] warne a man
Yet leave not off thy courſe begun,
If he to thee be dear.
With jangling fellows, full of words,
For ſpeech is common unto all,
So love thy Friends, as to thy ſelf,
So bound thy Bounty to the beſt,
Flee Tales and Rumors; Leaſt of News
For ſilence ſeldom hurts a Man,
But ſpeech much care hath wrought.
On truſt to others words, make thou
For Faith and Truth is rare; Becauſe
Moſt mean not as they ſpeak.
When other Men commend thee moſt,
As thou believe not more their Words,
Then what thy ſelf does know.
Each pleaſure done thee by a friend,
But what to others thou haſt done,
When thou art old, and ſhalt report
And what thy ſelf did then.
Take no regard what Standers by
In time of wealth, remember woe;
All humane things are ordered ſo,
Since frail and doubtful is our life,
To live in hope of others Death,
If from thy poor well-wiſhing Friend
In thankful ways accept his love,
Since naked from the womb thou cam'ſt,
Dread not thy death, in time to come,
Who dreads his end, therein exiles
If Friends, to whom thou haſt been kind,
Accuſe not Fate; But blame thy ſelf:
The better to ſupply thy want,
Spare what thy hand hath got:
And that thou may'ſt thy penny ſave,
What in thy power reſts to perform
Leaſt [while thou would be civil thought,]
Who ſpeaks right fair and loves thee not,
So Art by Art is met withall,
Whoſe words are full of Wiles,
Moſt ſweetly ſounds the Fowlers call,
If wedded thou have Children ſtore,
Then train them up in honeſt Arts,
That each may learn to live.
Things that be cheap imagine dear,
So neither niggard to thy ſelf,
What fault thou finds with other Men,
Let not be found in thee,
Foul ſhame in him, that vice reproves,
What is thy due, thou may'ſt require,
But folly were it, to deſire
A thing, thou ſhould not have.
Things known, before things never try'd
Sith thoſe by Judgment are diſcern'd,
Since Life in daily danger lyes,
Each day thou liv'ſt account thou gain,
Sometimes, when thou may'ſt Victor be,
Great things requiring, grudge thou not,
For by this means 'twixt Friend and Friend,
With whom thou art in League of Love,
Brauls hatred breeds, and friendſhip breaks;
When careleſs Servants move thy mind
Do nought in choler, till the time
Whom thou by force may'ſt conquer, ſeek
Of moral Virtues wiſe Men hold
Keep rather Goods by labour got,
Than ſpend till things be ſcant:
In loſs to work and toill afreſh,
Is ſtill to live in want.
Yet ſo as always of thy ſelf,

div.head: The PREFACE.
div.l: OF Tillage if perhaps thou would,
The Skill exactly know.
Read Learned Virgil, whoſe Diſcourſe
Each thing at large doth ſhow.
But if of Herbs and Plants the Force
Thou rather wiſh to find,
Lo Macer writtes a Book in Verſe,
To ſatisfy thy Mind.
• f Roman Warrs and bloody Broils
Of Carthage pleaſe thee more:
Search Lucan, who of Mars his Stirres
And Stratagems hath ſtore.
Or if by reading thou deſire,
The Laws of Love to Learn,
In Naſoes wanton Legend, lo,
This Art thou may'st diſcern.
But if thy chiefest Care intend,
A wiſe Mans ſtate to ſee:
Then listen thou to lead a Life
From filthy Vices free.
Approach, I ſay, and to my Lore.
Attend while I relate,
What Wiſdom is, and how by her,
Thou may'st be fortunate.

lg.l: Do good, in time of need:
For friends, by love and bounty won,
What heaven and Gods high ſecrets are,
VVaſte not thy wits to learn:
Since thou art mortal, mind the things
Fond fear of Death abandon quite,
Which, who ſo dreads, all joy of life,
Which wit and judgement ſo beguiles,
Spare for no coſt, when time ſhall ſerve,
A penny better ſpent then ſpar'd,
Safe is the bark on calmer ſtreames
Think not that men offending oft
Their faults: but that one time ſhall ſure
A man of limbs and ſtature ſmall
For Natur's want by wiſdomes wealth
Take heed in time to yeeld:
Againſt thy freind, by force of words,
Sometimes of words (which are but wind)
By lot, to know or ſhun.
Which (though it hurt not,) to endure
Old Sores to rub, and wrath revive,
To praiſe or diſcommend thy ſelf,
For ſo do fools whom glory vain,
In midſt of plenty, keep a mean,
Spend not thy ſelf too faſt:
Goods, long in gathering, oft are ſeen
To play the fool in time and place
Small Credit crave his idle Words
The Sin of Surfet pardon not:
Not Wine, but Drinkers foul Abuſe,
Thy Secrets to a ſecret Friend,
Thy crazed Body to his Truſt,
And arme thy ſelf to bear;
So ſhall thou in expected Broiles,
In time of trouble, be not like
But hope the beſt: For Hope alone
Old Father Time hath hairy Locks
Look back what follows, and withal
This Wiſdom may that Embleme teach,
Sometimes, for Health, ſpare dyet uſe;
Dame Pleaſure crave; Yet to thy Health
Leſt while thou many Men contemn'ſt
Thy ſelf be lik'd of none.
Of wiſhed Health have chiefeſt Care,
If evil Dyet make thee ſick,
Blame not the Spring nor Fall.
Regard not Dreams; For what Mens Thoughs
And wiſh, or hope, then muſe upon,

div.head: The PREFACE.
div.l: GOOD Reader, whoſoe're thou art,
That takes this Book in Hand,
Theſe brief Directions good for Life,
Give heed to understand.
With honest Precepts ſtore thy Mind,
Learn well their wiſe Contents.
For Life of civil Learning void,
Death's Image repreſents,
Great Profite may'ſt thou reap thereby,
Which if thou not reſpect,
Not me the Writer, but thy ſelf
Thou chiefly ſhalt neglect.

lg.l: WHereas thou lead'ſt an upright life,
Thou canſt not rule Mens tongues.

〈◊〉
•• ll'd by law, againſt thy Friend,
Of fawning words and flatt'ring ſpeech,
Flee beaſtly ſloth, the bane of life:
An idle mind decayes it ſelf,
To make both mind and body ſtrong,
But in thy many careful toils
To carp at others words, let not
Leaſt by thine own example taught,
Keep and encreaſe, that common Fame
Of Riches, if thy latter age
Sage counſel from thy Servants mouth,
• or any Mens advice, that may
If wonted wealth and ſubſtance fail,
• nd live content with what the times,
Beware thou marry not a Wife,
And if ſhe falſity her Faith,
An others Life, in this behalf,
Attempt not matters paſt thy ſtrength,
Thy Labour fail: and ſo thy work
What ill thou know'ſt of others wrought
Spare not in time to tell:
Leſt by thy ſilence thou ſubſcribe,
and ſeem to like it well.
To bear thou muſt not grudge;
For guilty to thy ſelf in ought,
Thy ſelf thou ought to judge.
Improve thy ſelf by Reading much,
At Feaſts and Banquets buſie not
Thy Tongue, with too much chat:
Leſt while thou would be pleaſant thought,
The Speeches of thy angry Wife,
For Women with their wylie Tears,
Uſe that thou haſt, to do thee good,
But ſee thou make no waſte;
Who vainly ſpend their own, and want,
Reſolve, fond fear of future Death
Which, though it be not good it ſelf,
Yet makes an end of ill.
And to offend thy Mother dear

div.head: The PREFACE.
div.l: WHOSO thou art that do'st deſire
To lead a quiet Life,
And touching Manners, to eſchew
Corruptions that are riſe.
This little Volume oft revolve,
Wherein thy ſelf ſhalt find
Such Precepts, grave as (Tutor-like,)
May teach and rule thy Mind.

lg.l: Dame Natures Wealth he cannot want,
And meaſures his Expence, with what
Through want of care, if thine Affairs
Love Money well; but to the ſtamp
Put not thy mind in thrall:
If thou be rich, beſtow the more
A rich Man ſick hath ſtore of Coin,
If of thy Maſter thou receive
In things that profite may procure,
What thou may'ſt give, from him that craves
For why to benefite the beſt,
Suſpecting ought to find it out,
For things, at firſt neglected, prove
Forbear to feed on coſtly Meats,
I only wiſh thee to avoid
Not ſtrength of able Limbs alone,
Seek Comfort of thy conſtant Friend,
For no Phyſician in his Cure,
For thine Offence, why ſhould thy Beaſt
To hope for Health by others Death,
A good Companion, or a Friend
Regard not what his Fortunes are:
Make uſe of Wealth, and ſcorn the Name
What good do Riches to tho Man
That ſtarves in midſt of ſtore?
If thou deſire in Life and Death
All Earthly pleaſures, vain and vile,
In things to thee more plain,
For whoſo lives till he be Old,
For Speech Mens Manners doth cnoceal
Though learned, yet thy Studies grave
As labour keeps the hand in uſe,
Regard not how the Fates conſpire
In time to work thee Spight;
He dreads not Death, in doubtful Life
Learn; But of ſuch as learned are,
For knowledge, where it may do good,
Drink what thou canſt: For forced Draughts
What ever thing thou ſhalt approve,
In time of calme and quiet reſt,
Again in trouble hope the beſt,
To learning ſtill thy mind apply,
That time at length ſhall manifeſt
Bluſh not, of Ignorance, to ſhew
As wit's a glory, ſo ſcandalous for thoſe,
In Wine and Women (wiſe men ſay)
What therefore is in either bad
For when the ſtream is calmeſt, there
Cloſe by the ſhoar to keep
Is ſafer, then to hoiſe up Sails
Againſt a juſt and upright man,
For God in juſtice doth revenge
Nor vex thy ſelf in vain:
Be rather merry, if thou may'ſt
To ſuffer loſs of all, a wrack
Yet things there are, which patiently
In no wayes promiſe, to thy ſelf,
For like a ſhadow at the back,
With incenſe make the Altar ſmoak,
Give Fortune place, and bear thy ſelf
For he that knows to yeeld in time,
In cureing wounds one ſmart (we ſee)
And change his manners; yet reſpect
To gain the greater Love of all,
Leſt thou incurr the Name of one,
Flee vain Suſpicions, leſt thou lead
VVhen for thy proper uſe thou buyer
And call'ſt them Slaves; Remember yet
Leſt afterwards thou ſeek in vain,
Rejoice not in the ſudden Death,
For Saints, whoſe Lives unſpotted are,
If thou be poor, and haſt withall
Barre ſuch, as by the Name of Friends,
Although by Studies thou be brought,
Yet ſhew thy ſelf in things unknown
And wonder, not that plaineſt words
